results.content:
It's good if you are familiar with OOP and PDO, and has a lot of projects  to keep you busy, and the instructor is eloquent and knows his stuff. 

However, after the first 3 projects it became hard to keep up with, especially with all the copy/pasting of classes, and most of the code in general  ... and I found myself pausing a lot to google things that I didn't understand.

If you have a solid knowledge of OOP, you'll find this course right up your alley, however, if you're still trying to get your head around it, you might want to learn more about OOP before diving into this one.

results.content:
I like these courses series I actually bought a bunch of them a while ago and I am just following through now.

The problem is that is a little bit off that sometimes the instructor(who I think is very knowledgeable) explain topics so simple like data types or loops and that is great, but he sometimes expends quite a bit time in this and when it comes  to more advanced topics like in the talking space project, he doesn't bother explaining what some notation means or why are objects or methods are structured  in a certain way he just copy and paste the code and says "O.k this does this".

I'm sorry but if is necessary to explain how a conditional works is also necessary to explain what a static method is or how do you call it (E.G PDO::) or why does methods lose the $ symbol when called (EG $this->stmt). or why do we use $this.

I've noticed it so far in this course and in the node.js course (where I am also going to leave a review ).

This is a great course I love the project oriented approach and it goes through some great concepts. I only wish you could fix this. You don't have to do the classes again I think if you just leave a simple comment with this syntax or concepts with a link to some documentation (such as the php manual) it should be enough. 

I'm change the review to a full 5 star because I really like the courses you guys offer but I think this is a necessary change you cannot take some time explaining really basic concepts and then just copy and paste advanced code without any guidance or reference. 

Obviously we can investigate this concepts by ourselves(like I did) but if it is in the course is really distracting having to go of topic to another website or finding reference about it instead of  maybe making a note like "At the end of this lecture we have some links to help you understand the concepts covered here".

I hope you guys don't think my review is too harsh, as I said, I think you are doing a great job I just think you should polish some things a little bit.

Thank you and have a great day.

results.content:
I am a decent coder, but the instructor's need to go from one framework to another made it difficult, I never got CakePHP to install properly (it's not as easy as shown in the video, because the folk at Cake have updated things ...); Code Igniter is horribly confusing and frustrating to work with. The instructor does a lot of copying and pasting of code, which in some ways makes a lot of sense -- however, there are times when he pastes the code and switches to another file before you have a chance to look at it, requiring you to back up the video, etc. In attempting to do next to last project (KewlCMS) I tried it *three times* from the beginning, and because CodeIgniter has changed internal mechanics, some of the code doesn't work. I copied code directly from the instructor's "final" source code for the project, and editing doesn't work (no errors, but "Save" button does not go anywhere) and delete in all areas in the Admin section brings up errors. Very frustrating. 

Feeling like I should not be completely negative, I did learn some things from the course (and not just "Don't use CakePHP or Code Igniter") -- I learned some ideas for structuring my code more efficiently, and the work with the PHP Data Object abilities are interesting, and I will be revisiting some of the projects for this course as I move forward ...

results.content:
Mostly it's been good & I've learnt a lot.  I've had a few issues with the material.  I think that I'm using a newer version of PHP, which has caused a couple of issues & some of the Bootstrap class names have changed.  There's a weird issue with the topic.php template, but I searched the Q&A and found where a couple of the users had found a work-around.  Still not sure why it works, changing the name to topico.php, but it does. 

After completing the course, I have to say that projects 8 & 9 seriously affected my rating of the course.  I spent almost as much time troubleshooting things on them as I did doing the projects.  As the course is getting somewhat dated now, it might be nice to include some information at the start of the course that lets people know that parts of the course are not compatible with current versions of PHP, Bootstrap, CodeIgniter & CakePHP.  Some info about how they can setup a downgraded environment might enable people to complete the projects with a bit less frustration.

I also didn't like Brad's decision to tour as many frameworks as possible.  I can understand the frontend frameworks as they make the setup for the frontend quicker, but since it was a PHP course, not a CodeIgniter or CakePHP course there wasn't really enough time for me to get even a basic understanding of how these frameworks function.  I just know we put a bunch of code in a bunch of seemingly random locations and the only real reason I got was because that's how the framework wants it to be.

I would have preferred it if he had not used CodeIgniter or CakePHP but just mentioned that they were options to speed up programming in PHP (maybe with links to courses for either of those for people who were interested).  Failing that it would have been more useful to do all the framework projects in one framework so I could get some sort of understanding of what was going on with it.

The first part of the course was great.  I felt like I learnt a great deal that I could immediately put into practice, but I don't feel I could put together even the most basic project in either of the PHP frameworks without doing more study on them, because there wasn't a lot of explanation of why we were putting files in particular places, or why certain code should go in a model file, or a controller file, or a view file.

results.content: This course is NOT for beginners! The first two projects are simple, after that the learning curve is pretty steep. You need to have some experience in PHP and object-oriented programming (OOP) to understand it. The course is a bit outdated. I couldn't follow the Project 8 (JobFind), because the old CakePHP framework used in it was incompatible with the new PHP7. The Project 9 (Kewl CMS) is unfinished, but it isn't a big deal - students get enough knowledge to finish it themselves. However, it would be nice to have the full complete code. Apart from these minor drawbacks, it's a useful and interesting course, and I can highly recommend it.

Instructtor is very knowledgeable on the subject. The course is presented with increasing difficulty and subject on each chapter is built on top the previous chapter.

I took rob percival's complete developer course and jumped right into this, meaning I am a complete newbie in web developing. Althought difficult but I was able to follow the first 3 projects and making everything work. Thus learning quite a bit. 

However on the 4th project the instructor used lots of new and more complex techniques. and since he has the project pre built, so in order to save time he would paste large chunk of code and quickly explain what those pasted codes do. Thus it is more like showcasing what php is capable of instead of walking you through how the php does it. Lots of frustrated students can be found at this section of the course. 

I bought the course for $20, I think it is still worth it but now I cannot progress any further until I find another course or self learning to fill in the gap.

results.content:
On the plus side, I like the whole 'projects-oriented' approach. I like the teaching style and usually, Brad explains even complex things in an easy way. And for the first time, someone explained the object-oriented programming in a way that I could relate to, including the use of constructors etc.
I also like the fact that he starts with the design of his project (the bare html - the UI) and then goes into the inner functioning (data handling, processing etc)
I would have given a higher rating if it wasn't for the following:
- No documentation, no outline: it would be nice to have a brief intro and outline (with the basic steps) at the beginning of each project in a powerpoint or similar worksheet to be able to refer back to, not just spoken text!
- Brad promises several times to use a proper IDE instead of Notepad++ (which I do like, but is not suitable for more complex projects); he promises but never fulfills.
- This would also have prevented him from making those little, but time-consuming coding errors ...
But at the end of the day I have to admit that I still learned a lot - despite those shortcomings. The projects are a good incentive to dig deeper, to learn, to investigate (if something doesn't work at the first try) and to improve and add more features.

results.content:
The main issue with this course is as the projects get more complex, if you make a mistake you are often stuck figuring it out on your own. The instructor will reply "Have you compared your code to my code" to almost every question.  Reading through the QA I can say support is pretty bad, often with the instructor never replying to a student. 

The other main issue is that this course does not really explain the "why" behind much of what you are doing. If you take the time to read the docs and other online help boards you can generally figure out what something does but it isn't always apperent off the bat. The course claims you only need a basic understanding of PHP and HTML but I think that unless you already have solid HTML/CSS skills, and a grasp on OOP concepts you might struggle if you have never coded in another language.

That being said, there is a lot of good info, projects scale up in complexity well. I personally like the teaching style, and it's good to see the mistakes as they happen and watch the process for figuring out how to fix them. I would recommend this if you have a basic grasp on PHP, solid HTML/CSS skills, and know (at least conceptually) about OOP and are looking to see how it all comes together to make real web apps.

results.content:
I LIKE the information. I LOVE codeigniter. The course is a little frustrating. The instructor is somewhat hard to follow on occasion especially immediately after pasting (frequently) in code, he moves his display around quickly & abruptly and it is a bit dizzying. Fortunately, this is a video course and he provides course code for each lesson. I can pause the video and go through his code line by line, creating my code as I go by hand. I don't cut and paste, I type in every line, because I want to get a feel and familiarity with each line of PHP so that I can try to get a fuller understanding of what is being done.

Perhaps because the course isn't a perfectly smooth presentation I'm actually learning more. I know I am putting more effort into the course as a result.  I do frequent the Q&A sections and sites like stackoverflow.com when I have a problem.

But I definitely know more after going this course than before. It is worthwhile.

results.content: Wish I could leave a higher score, because it did have exactly what I was looking for. Namely, I had the basics of all the covered languages pretty well down, but I wanted a better sense of how professional websites should be structured. If you are in a similar position I highly recommend this course. However, the lessons themselves are not professionally structured. If you are not pretty well familiar with web languages you will not not be able to keep up with what is going on. The instructor will choose random places to explain something in depth, but it's not helpful. You are basically just watching someone make websites. Also, the version of Bootstrap used is WAAAAY out of date, and you will not be able to follow a number of the units directly, rather you will have to adjust them to make them work. If you have worked a little with bootstrap before, this means they take some extra time but it is a good learning experience. IF YOU ARE A BOOTSTRAP NOVICE THIS COURSE WILL NOT WORK FOR YOU. In summary, if you are reasonably proficient in the languages (and Bootstrap) and want to learn structure, this course is swell. If you are unsure of yourself with syntax, go elsewhere first.
